settings.restoreStateFromBackupDialogDescription: Restoring from backup will replace the current settings, erasing all previous data, and will restart the application. This action cannot be undone.
settings.resetStateDialogDescription: Resetting the app will erase all data and restart the application. This action cannot be undone.
settings.useLinuxCompatibleBluetoothApiDescriptio: Enable this option if you are using a Linux-based system and having problems connecting to hubs. Enabling this option may increase connection latency. Changes will affect only new connections.
settings.gamepadPollRateDescription: Low poll rate may reduce CPU usage, but will also increase input lag.

keyboard.captureNonAlphaNumericsHint: In some scenarios, capturing non-alphanumeric keys may prevent you from using your keyboard normally. Use this option with caution.

steamDeckInstallation.name: Steam Deck
steamDeckInstallation.general: This guide will help you install MOC Commander on your Steam Deck and use it in gaming mode to control your LEGO® Powered UP MOCs.

step1.title: Step 1. Install Google Chrome
step1.description: To use MOC Commander application, you need to install Google Chrome browser (or any other browser that supports Web Bluetooth API).
step1.description2: The list of supported browsers can be found at
step1.description3: , however, this manual will focus on Google Chrome.
step1.switchToDesktop: Press the Steam button to bring up the Steam Deck menu and select "Power" -> "Switch to Desktop"
step1.openDiscover: Open the Discover app on taskbar
step1.closeDiscover: After the installation is complete, close the Discover app

step2.title: Step 2. Enable Bluetooth support in Google Chrome
step2.description: By default, Google Chrome does not support Bluetooth devices on Linux. To enable Bluetooth support, follow the steps below:
step2.openChrome: Open the Application Launcher on the taskbar, select "Internet" -> "Google Chrome"
step2.pasteFlagsUrl: Paste the following URL into the address bar
step2.enableFeature: Toggle the "Experimental Web Platform features" to "Enabled"
step2.restartChrome: Press the "Relaunch" button to restart Google Chrome
step2.result: Now, you can use MOC Commander in desktop mode and use Steam Input in keyboard mode to control your MOCs.

step3.title: Step 3. (Optional) Allow Google Chrome to install PWA & access gamepad devices
step3.openKonsole: Close Google Chrome and open the Konsole app (Application Launcher -> "System" -> "Konsole")
step3.enterCommand: Enter the following command and press Enter:
step3.enterCommandMotivation: This command will allow Google Chrome to install the MOC Commander app and access gamepad devices.

step4.title: Step 4. (Optional) Install MOC Commander and add it to Steam Client Library
step4.installPwa: Press "Install" button in the top right corner
step4.confirmInstall: Press the "Install" button in the popup window. The app will launch automatically
step4.closeAll: Close both Google Chrome and the MOC Commander app
step4.openAddNonSteamGame: Open the Steam Client, select "Library," and press "Add a Game" -> "Add a Non-Steam Game"
step4.addMocCommander: Find "MOC Commander" in the list, toggle the checkbox, and click "Add Selected Programs"
step4.returnToGamingMode: Return to gaming mode by double-tapping the "Return To Gaming Mode" icon on the desktop
step4.result: The app should appear in the Steam Client Library under the "Non-Steam" category.
step4.following: Now you can use MOC Commander in game mode with full support of Steam Input.

step5.title: Step 5. (Optional) Set starting resolution for MOC Commander
step5.description: By default, the application will launch at a lower resolution than the screen resolution of the Steam Deck. To set the starting resolution to the maximum available, follow the steps below:
step5.openAppProperties: Find "MOC Commander" in the Steam Client Library and open its properties ("Gear Icon" -> "Properties")
step5.addOption: In "Launch Options," add a space at the end of the line and the following option:
step5.result: Now, the application will launch at the maximum available resolution.
step5.toExitDesktop: To exit the application while in desktop mode, press L5 + R5 and then - 'Stop' in the Steam Client
step5.toExitGameMode: To exit the application in game mode, press the Steam button and select "Exit game".

windowsInstallation.name: Windows
windowsInstallation.general: This guide will help you install MOC Commander as a standalone app on your Windows PC and use it to control your LEGO® Powered UP MOCs with your keyboard, mouse and gamepads.

step1.title: Step 1. Install Google Chrome
step1.description: To use MOC Commander application, you need to install Google Chrome browser (or any other browser that supports Web Bluetooth API) from official website or Microsoft Store
step1.description2: The list of supported browsers can be found at
step1.description3: , however, this manual will focus on Google Chrome.

step2.title: Step 2. (Optional) Install MOC Commander as a an app
step2.description: To use MOC Commander as a standalone app, follow the steps below:
step2.installPwa: Press "Install" button in the top right corner
step2.confirmInstall: Press the "Install" button in the popup window. The app will launch automatically
step2.result: This will install MOC Commander as a PWA app and add it to the Start menu and the desktop.

step1.title: Step 1. Install Google Chrome using your package manager or download it from the official website

step2.title: Step 2. Enable Bluetooth support in Google Chrome
step2.description: By default, Google Chrome does not support Bluetooth devices on Linux. To enable Bluetooth support, follow the steps below:
step2.pasteFlagsUrl: Paste the following URL into the address bar
step2.enableFeature: Toggle the "Experimental Web Platform features" to "Enabled"
step2.restartChrome: Press the "Relaunch" button to restart Google Chrome

1-1-0.featAddInstallationInstructions: Installation instructions for Steam Deck, Windows, and Linux
1-1-0.featAddSteamDeckControllerProfile: Addition of a Steam Deck controller profile
1-1-0.featMakeAppInstallableAsPWA: The app is now installable as a PWA (Progressive Web App)

1-2-0.featUnsavedChangesNotifications: Notifications for unsaved changes on pages with forms
1-2-0.featWakeLock: Wake Lock to prevent the screen from turning off when a control scheme is running
1-2-0.featAxialAwarenessForStepperTrainAndGear: Axial input direction awareness for 'Stepper', 'Train', and 'Gearbox' bindings
1-2-0.featReadAndSetMotorPositionDuringControl: Ability to read and set motor position during editing of 'Set angle' and 'Gearbox' bindings

1-2-1.featAppUpdatedNotification: Display of a notification when the app is updated

1-2-2.featSeparateControlsForServoCwAndCcw: Separate controls for servo clockwise and counter-clockwise inputs
1-2-2.featMotorPositionAdjustment: Fine-grained motor position adjustment during editing of 'Set angle', 'Servo', and 'Gearbox' bindings
1-2-2.featUseLinuxCompatSetting: Linux-compatible connection mode setting is now available in the app settings

1-2-3.featRaiseServoMotorRangeLimit: Increased servo motor range limit to 4 full rotations (1440°)
1-2-3.featSeparateControlsForForwardAndBackwar: Separate controls for forward and backward speed in 'Speed' bindings
1-2-3.featDirectionAwareControls: All binding input controls now adhere to the input direction of gamepad axes
1-2-3.featSeparateControlsForCwCcwStepper: Separate controls for clockwise and counter-clockwise stepper inputs
1-2-3.changeStepperNegativeValuesRemoved: Only positive values are allowed for step angle in 'Stepper' binding. Use counter-clockwise controller input for negative values
1-2-3.featAcquireWakeLockWhenAtLeastOneHubIsCo: Acquire Wake Lock when at least one hub is connected
1-2-3.featInputGainForBrakeInputOfSpeedBinding: Input gain for 'Brake' input of 'Speed' binding
1-2-3.featHubHWAndSWVersionInHubInfo: Display of hub hardware and software versions in the hub info panel

1-2-4.featOnOffToggleInputPreset: On/off toggle mode for 'Speed' and 'Servo' binding inputs
1-2-4.featSeparatePitchYawRollTiltSensorWidget: Separate pitch, yaw, and roll tilt sensor widgets

1-2-5.appIconUpdated: Updated app icon (now it displays correctly during the process of adding the app to the Steam Client Library)
1-2-5.servoManualRangeReadFix: Fixed manual servo range read from port during binding editing
1-2-5.servoCenterOnStartForKeyInputsFix: Fixed servo not centering on start when using key or button inputs

1-2-6.fixServoCalibrationForRangesGraterThan36: Fixed servo calibration for ranges greater than 360°
1-2-6.fixServoCalibrationResultsNotBeingRound: Fixed servo calibration results not being rounded to the nearest degree
1-2-6.fixMultipleServoCalibrationOnStartup: Fixed issue with incorrect results of multiple servo calibration on startup
1-2-6.featMotorStrainingReduction: Reduced motor straining at the ends of the servo range received during calibration

1-2-7.compactRedesignControlSchemes: Compact redesign of the control schemes list for better usability on smaller screens
1-2-7.runningControlSchemePerformanceImproveme: Performance improvements for running control schemes
1-2-7.fixPwaBackgroundColor: Fixed background color of the PWA app
1-2-7.fixHighFrequencyTaskStalling: Fixed task stalling when processing high-frequency inputs

1-2-8.addGamepadPollingRateSettings: Gamepad polling rate option added to the settings
1-2-8.increaseGamepadPollingRate: Increased default gamepad poll rate. Previous value is now considered 'Low' in the settings
1-2-8.fixWidgetUpdatesAfterSchemeStartFailure: Fixed widgets continuing to update after a control scheme start failure
